DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to determine if a telephone social support and empowerment intervention is more effective than usual community services in improving the mental health of community-dwelling women abused by their intimate partners.
DOC.brief_title: Effectiveness of a Telephone Intervention to Improve the Mental Health of Abused Women
DOC.detailed_description: Depression is one of the most common mental health sequelae of intimate partner violence (IPV). Although a range of interventions have been tried to improve the mental health of women survivors of IPV, the results are inconclusive. In this trial, a 12-week advocacy intervention consisting of empowerment and telephone social support is provided to abused Chinese women in a community setting. Usual community services provide the control condition.
DOC.criteria: Chinese women 18 years of age or older Selfreport of psychological, physical or sexual abuse by their current or former intimate partner in the previous 12 months Live or work in a community within the catchment area of a community centre designated for the proposed study Perpetrator is not an intimate partner
